p: Conservation genetics is a discipline that incorporates genetic information into the planning and management of threatened species to minimise extinction risk. Genomic measures of relatedness, connectivity, and differentiation can be applied in a broad context to identify and clarify taxonomic issues and to identify evolutionarily divergent lineages within species [ 52]. At a local level, conservation managers can use genetic information to monitor gene flow and landscape genetics, as well as population parameters such as heterozygosity, genetic drift, and levels of inbreeding [ 14, 53]. Genetics has also been used to inform pedigrees and breeding programs for endangered species in captivity by determining factors such as individual fitness and kinship [ 18, 54, 55].
